objects.name: TFA Matrix Extension
objects.description: Extension properties for the Tech-Facilitated Abuse (TFA) Matrix framework.

x_tfa_public_title.description: Plain-language technique title for public/victim-facing display

x_tfa_public_summary.description: Accessible technique description for victims and the general public

x_tfa_public_safety_warning.description: Safety-critical warning. Null if no special warning needed

x_tfa_public_notices.description: Array of observable signals in everyday language: [{signal, detail}]

x_tfa_public_actions.description: Array of protective actions in everyday language: [{action, detail, safety_note}]

objects.name: Not A Standard
objects.description: Security and intelligence consultancy specializing in contested knowledge domains. Developer of the SAFE Framework and TFA Matrix.

definition.statement: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. To view a copy of this license, visit https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/. Attribution: TFA Matrix by SAFE Framework / Not A Standard.

objects.name: TFA Matrix
objects.description: The Technology-Facilitated Abuse (TFA) Matrix is a structured knowledge base of tactics and techniques used in technology-facilitated abuse, developed by Not A Standard as part of the SAFE Framework.

objects.name: Surveillance & Tracking
objects.description: The adversary is trying to monitor the victim's location, activities, communications, and relationships without consent or beyond consent given. Surveillance techniques enable perpetrators to maintain awareness of victim movements, predict behavior, and gather information for use in other tactics.
objects.x_tfa_public_intro: These are ways someone might be monitoring where you go, who you talk to, and what you do — often without you knowing.
objects.x_tfa_public_safety: If you suspect you're being tracked, be careful about suddenly changing your behaviour. The person monitoring you may notice and escalate. Consider getting support before making changes.

objects.name: Account & Access Compromise
objects.description: The adversary is trying to gain unauthorized access to victim's accounts, devices, or digital identity, or deny victim access to their own. These techniques enable perpetrators to control victim's digital presence, access private information, and restrict victim's autonomy.
objects.x_tfa_public_intro: These are ways someone might access your accounts, lock you out of your own devices, or take control of your digital identity.
objects.x_tfa_public_safety: Changing passwords can alert the other person. If you're in an unsafe situation, plan your digital safety steps with support from a service like 1800RESPECT.

objects.name: Harassment & Intimidation
objects.description: The adversary is directly threatening, frightening, humiliating, or exhausting victim through digital means. These techniques create fear, emotional distress, and psychological harm through sustained digital aggression.
objects.x_tfa_public_intro: These are ways someone might use technology to threaten, scare, humiliate, or overwhelm you.
objects.x_tfa_public_safety: Save evidence of threats and harassment — screenshots with dates. If you feel you're in immediate danger, contact 000.

objects.name: Information Manipulation
objects.description: The adversary is trying to control, distort, fabricate, or weaponize information to harm victim's reality, reputation, or relationships. These techniques undermine victim's credibility, social support, and sense of reality.
objects.x_tfa_public_intro: These are ways someone might manipulate digital information to harm you — changing messages, creating fake content, or damaging your reputation.
objects.x_tfa_public_safety: Trust your memory and your experience. Keep your own records. If someone is making you doubt what you know to be true, that itself is a warning sign.

objects.name: Isolation & Control
objects.description: The adversary is trying to cut victim off from support networks, control their communications, or restrict their digital autonomy. These techniques reduce victim's ability to seek help, maintain relationships, or exercise independent judgment.
objects.x_tfa_public_intro: These are ways someone might use technology to separate you from the people who care about you, or control how you communicate.
objects.x_tfa_public_safety: If someone is controlling your access to communication, try to find one safe way to reach out — a trusted friend's phone, a library computer, or a service like 1800RESPECT.

objects.name: Resource & Financial Control
objects.description: The adversary is trying to control, restrict, or exploit victim's financial resources and economic independence through technology. These techniques create financial dependency, economic harm, and material vulnerability.
objects.x_tfa_public_intro: These are ways someone might use technology to control your finances, restrict your economic independence, or exploit your resources.
objects.x_tfa_public_safety: Financial abuse can be harder to recognise than other forms. If someone controls all the money and you can't make independent financial decisions, that's a warning sign.

objects.name: Physical Enablement
objects.description: The adversary is using technology to enable, coordinate, or amplify physical-world harm. These techniques bridge digital abuse to physical danger, representing the most severe escalation of tech-facilitated abuse.
objects.x_tfa_public_name: Using Tech to Enable Physical Harm
objects.x_tfa_public_intro: These are ways someone might use technology to enable or carry out physical harm, control your physical environment, or interfere with your safety.
objects.x_tfa_public_safety: If you are in immediate danger, contact 000. These techniques involve real physical safety risks — please reach out to a support service for safety planning.

objects.name: Stalkerware Installation
objects.description: Installing hidden monitoring software on victim's device to track location, messages, calls, photos, and keystrokes. Stalkerware (also called spouseware or creepware) is commercially available software marketed for 'parental monitoring' or 'employee tracking' but frequently used for intimate partner surveillance. These apps typically hide their presence, run silently in the background, and transmit data to the perpetrator.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone installs a hidden app on your phone or computer that secretly tracks your location, reads your messages, and monitors your calls — without anything visible on screen.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: If you think there's a monitoring app on your phone, don't remove it straight away. The person who installed it may be alerted and could become dangerous. Get advice from a specialist service first.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your phone battery is draining much faster than usual
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Monitoring apps run constantly in the background, which uses a lot of battery power.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You're using more mobile data than expected
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: The app sends your information to the other person, which uses data — even when you're not actively using your phone.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your phone feels warm even when you're not using it
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Background monitoring processes generate heat.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person seems to know things they shouldn't
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They mention details from your private messages, know where you've been, or reference conversations they weren't part of.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You notice unfamiliar apps or settings on your device
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Look for apps you don't recognise, or device administrator settings you didn't set up.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Use a stalkerware detection app to check your phone
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Apps like those recommended by the Coalition Against Stalkerware can scan for known monitoring software.
x_tfa_public_actions.safety_note: Running a scan is generally safe — the monitoring person typically can't see that you've installed a detection app.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Keep your phone locked with a PIN or biometric
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Use a strong passcode that the other person doesn't know. Avoid patterns that are easy to watch and copy.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Consider getting a separate safe phone
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: A prepaid phone the other person doesn't know about can be used for sensitive calls and messages.
x_tfa_public_actions.safety_note: Keep it hidden and don't connect it to any accounts the other person knows about.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Keep your phone's software up to date
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Updates fix security holes that monitoring apps exploit.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Get a professional to examine your device
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: A digital forensic specialist can find hidden monitoring software and preserve evidence.
x_tfa_public_actions.safety_note: Ask a support service for referrals — don't search for this on a monitored device.

objects.name: Physical Tracker Planting
objects.description: Placing GPS tracking devices such as AirTags, Tile trackers, or vehicle GPS units in victim's belongings, vehicle, or on their person without consent. These commercially available devices are inexpensive, small, and designed for long battery life, making covert placement easy. Perpetrators use them to monitor victim's movements, identify frequented locations, and anticipate travel patterns.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone places a small tracking device — like an AirTag, Tile, or GPS tracker — in your bag, car, or belongings to follow your movements.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: If you find a tracker, think carefully before removing it. Removing it tells the other person you found it. Document it first (photo with date) and get advice.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your phone alerts you about an unknown tracker travelling with you
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: iPhones and some Android phones will warn you if an unknown AirTag or similar device is nearby for a long time.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person always seems to know where you are
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They reference specific places you've been, your routes, or when you arrived somewhere — without you telling them.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You find a small unfamiliar device in your things
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Trackers can be small — about the size of a coin. Check under seats, in wheel wells, inside bag pockets, or attached to keyrings.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You hear periodic beeping from your bag or car
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Some trackers beep to help owners find them. If you hear unexplained beeping, investigate.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Enable unknown tracker alerts on your phone
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: On iPhone, this is on by default. Android users can download the Tracker Detect app or enable similar built-in features.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Check your car systematically
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Look under the chassis, in wheel wells, behind bumpers, in the boot, and under seats. A torch and mirror help.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Check your everyday bags and belongings
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Go through pockets, linings, and any compartments. Feel for small hard objects that shouldn't be there.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Document before removing
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: If you find a tracker, photograph it in place with a timestamp. This preserves evidence.
x_tfa_public_actions.safety_note: Consider whether it's safer to leave it in place temporarily while you make a safety plan.

objects.name: Shared Account Surveillance
objects.description: Exploiting legitimately shared accounts or location sharing services (Find My Friends, Google location sharing, family phone plans) to monitor victim beyond the scope of original consent. Often occurs in relationships where sharing was mutual but continues after separation, or where the perpetrator coerces ongoing access under the guise of reasonable family coordination.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone uses accounts you share — like a family phone plan, streaming service, or cloud storage — to track your location, purchases, or activity.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: Changing shared account settings may alert the other person. Plan which accounts to separate first and do them in a safe order.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person knows about purchases, locations, or content you haven't shared
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Shared accounts like Google, Apple Family, or phone plans often show activity to all members.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You discover location sharing is turned on with their account
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Check your phone's location sharing settings — someone may have enabled sharing without you realising.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Unfamiliar devices appear in your account's trusted devices list
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Someone else's phone or computer may be logged into your shared accounts.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Review all location sharing settings on your devices
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: On iPhone: Settings > Privacy > Location Services > Share My Location. On Android: Google Maps > your profile > Location sharing.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Gradually move to your own individual accounts
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Create new accounts with a fresh email address the other person doesn't know about.
x_tfa_public_actions.safety_note: Do this from a device and network you're confident isn't monitored.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Check your phone plan
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Family plans often let the account holder see call logs, texts, and data usage for all lines.
x_tfa_public_actions.safety_note: Moving to your own plan is ideal, but timing matters — plan it.

objects.name: Social Media Monitoring
objects.description: Systematic observation of victim's public and semi-public social media activity, connections, check-ins, likes, comments, and tagged posts. May include creating fake accounts to follow private profiles, monitoring friends' posts for references to victim, or using social media analytics tools to track patterns of activity and connections.

x_tfa_evidence_types: Screenshots of perpetrator referencing monitored activity
Timestamps correlating online activity with perpetrator actions
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone closely monitors your social media accounts — tracking your posts, checking who you interact with, and using your activity to keep tabs on your life.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person comments on things you posted but didn't tell them about
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They reference photos, check-ins, or interactions they saw on your social media.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You notice unfamiliar accounts following you or viewing your stories
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They may have created fake accounts to watch you even after being blocked.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Friends mention the other person asking about your posts
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They may be monitoring through mutual contacts.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Tighten your privacy settings on every platform
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Set profiles to private. Review who can see your posts, stories, friends list, and tagged photos.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Review and clean up your followers and connections
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Remove accounts you don't recognise or that seem suspicious.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Stop posting real-time locations or future plans
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Share holiday photos after you're home. Don't tag your current location.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Turn off tagging or require approval for tags
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: This prevents friends from accidentally revealing your location through their posts.

objects.name: Communication Interception
objects.description: Accessing victim's emails, text messages, voicemails, and other communications through compromised accounts, email forwarding rules, message mirroring, or linked devices. Perpetrator reads, copies, or monitors communications without victim's knowledge, gaining intelligence about victim's plans, support network, and emotional state.

x_tfa_evidence_types: Message read receipts from unrecognized sessions
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone intercepts and reads your private messages, emails, or calls — either by accessing your accounts directly or by using software that copies your communications.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: If your communications are being intercepted, the other person can see your safety planning. Use a different device or in-person conversations for sensitive discussions.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Messages show as 'read' before you've opened them
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Someone else may be accessing your messaging accounts.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person responds to things said in private conversations
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They reference details from messages or calls you had with other people.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Email forwarding rules you didn't set up
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Check your email settings for auto-forwarding to unknown addresses.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Unfamiliar devices in your account's active sessions
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Most email and messaging services show which devices are currently logged in.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Check active sessions on all your accounts
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Gmail: Security > Your devices. Facebook: Settings > Security > Where you're logged in. Do this for all platforms.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Check for email forwarding rules
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: In Gmail: Settings > Forwarding. In Outlook: Settings > Mail > Forwarding. Remove anything you didn't set up.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Use end-to-end encrypted messaging for sensitive conversations
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Apps like Signal encrypt messages so only you and the recipient can read them.
x_tfa_public_actions.safety_note: Only useful if your device itself isn't compromised.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Change passwords from a safe device
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Use a device the other person hasn't had access to.
x_tfa_public_actions.safety_note: A trusted friend's phone or a library computer can work.

objects.name: Smart Home Surveillance
objects.description: Using shared smart home devices including cameras, video doorbells, baby monitors, voice assistants, and other IoT devices to monitor victim's presence, activities, conversations, and visitors. Often exploits devices installed during cohabitation where perpetrator retains administrative access after separation.

x_tfa_evidence_types: Account audit showing perpetrator admin access
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone uses smart home devices — cameras, doorbells, speakers, or home assistants — to watch, listen to, or record you in your own home.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: Smart home devices are often controlled by whoever set up the account. If you're in a shared home, the other person may have admin access to all devices.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Smart home devices behave unexpectedly
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Cameras move on their own, speakers activate without prompts, or lights/locks change without your input.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person knows what's happening inside the home
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They reference private conversations or activities that happened when they weren't present.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You can't control devices or change settings
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: You don't have admin access, or settings keep reverting after you change them.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Indicator lights on cameras or devices activate at odd times
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Small LED lights on cameras may blink when recording or being accessed remotely.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Check which accounts control your smart home devices
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Identify who has admin access to cameras, speakers, locks, and thermostats.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Physically disconnect devices you're concerned about
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Unplug cameras and smart speakers. Cover camera lenses with tape if you can't unplug.
x_tfa_public_actions.safety_note: The other person may notice if devices go offline.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Change Wi-Fi passwords
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: This disconnects all devices. You can then selectively reconnect only the ones you control.
x_tfa_public_actions.safety_note: Only do this if you safely control the router.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Do a factory reset on devices you want to keep
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: This removes previous account connections. Set them up fresh with your own account.

objects.name: Network Traffic Monitoring
objects.description: Monitoring victim's internet activity through router administrative access, DNS logs, or network monitoring tools. Perpetrator can see websites visited, search queries, app usage patterns, and connected devices. May install network-level monitoring tools or exploit existing router features.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone monitors your internet traffic through the home router or network — seeing which websites you visit, what you search for, and what services you use.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: If someone controls the home network, they may be able to see your browsing activity. Use mobile data instead of Wi-Fi for sensitive searches.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person knows what you've been searching or browsing
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They reference websites you visited or things you looked up.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Unfamiliar software on the router or network
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Network monitoring tools or DNS logging may have been enabled.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your internet seems slower than expected
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Monitoring tools can slightly slow down network traffic.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Use your mobile data for sensitive browsing
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Switch off Wi-Fi and use 4G/5G when searching for support services, legal help, or safety planning.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Use a VPN on your devices
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: A VPN encrypts your internet traffic so it can't be read by someone monitoring the network.
x_tfa_public_actions.safety_note: The other person may notice a VPN is installed on your device.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Check your router's settings
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Look for logging, monitoring, or DNS filtering features that may have been enabled.
x_tfa_public_actions.safety_note: Only access router settings if you're confident the other person won't notice.

objects.name: Calendar/Schedule Surveillance
objects.description: Accessing victim's calendar applications, booking systems, medical appointment portals, or work schedules to track movements and anticipate whereabouts. May exploit shared family calendars, compromised account access, or work systems to build a detailed picture of victim's routine.

x_tfa_evidence_types: Correlation of perpetrator appearances with calendar entries
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone monitors your calendar, schedule, or booking apps to know where you'll be and when — including appointments, meetings, and social plans.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person shows up at events or appointments they shouldn't know about
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They appear at places you only noted in your calendar.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: They reference your schedule without you telling them
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They mention meetings, appointments, or plans from your calendar.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your calendar is shared with accounts you don't recognise
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Check calendar sharing settings for unexpected connections.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Review calendar sharing settings
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: In Google Calendar: Settings > each calendar > Share with specific people. Remove anyone unexpected.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Keep a separate private calendar
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Use a different app or account for sensitive appointments — support services, legal consultations, etc.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Check which apps have access to your calendar
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: On your phone: Settings > Privacy > Calendar. Remove access for apps that don't need it.

objects.name: Third-Party Monitoring Recruitment
objects.description: Enlisting friends, family members, mutual contacts, or acquaintances (sometimes called 'flying monkeys') to monitor and report on victim's activities, location, companions, and emotional state. May involve deliberately maintaining relationships with victim's contacts for intelligence gathering purposes.

x_tfa_evidence_types: Messages from third parties reporting victim's activities
Correlation of third-party contact with perpetrator knowledge
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone convinces friends, family, neighbours, or mutual contacts to report back on your activities, either openly or without you knowing.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Information you only shared with specific people gets back to the other person
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Things you told a friend in confidence are known to someone who shouldn't know.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Mutual contacts ask unusually detailed questions
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: People start asking where you're going, who you're seeing, or what your plans are — more than feels natural.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You notice people watching or checking on you
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Neighbours, work colleagues, or acquaintances seem to be tracking your comings and goings.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Be thoughtful about what you share and with whom
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Consider which contacts might pass information to the other person, even without bad intent.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Create an inner circle of trusted people
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Identify a small number of people you trust completely and keep sensitive information within that circle.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Have a conversation with people you suspect are reporting back
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Sometimes people don't realise they're being used. A calm conversation may help.

objects.name: Fitness/Health Tracker Surveillance
objects.description: Monitoring victim through health and fitness applications, wearable trackers, period tracking apps, sleep monitors, or medical portals. These platforms often contain highly sensitive data about location, physical activity, health conditions, reproductive status, and daily routines.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone uses fitness trackers, health apps, or wearable devices to monitor your location, activity patterns, sleep, and health data.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person knows about your exercise routes or activity patterns
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They reference when and where you exercised, or your daily routine.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Health or fitness data is being shared with their account
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Shared fitness challenges, family health accounts, or linked apps may expose your data.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your wearable shows locations or activity you didn't do
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Someone else may be accessing and viewing your tracker data remotely.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Review sharing settings on fitness and health apps
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Check Fitbit, Apple Health, Strava, Garmin, and similar apps for shared access or linked accounts.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Remove exercise routes from public or shared view
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Many fitness apps share routes by default. Switch to private or remove location from activities.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Check who has access to your health data
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Apple Health: Settings > Health > Data Access. Google Fit: account settings > connected apps.

objects.name: Credential Theft
objects.description: Obtaining victim's passwords, PINs, or authentication credentials through shoulder surfing, guessing based on personal knowledge, social engineering, checking common password patterns, or accessing written password records. Intimate partners often have enough personal knowledge to guess passwords or know where credentials are stored.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone gets hold of your passwords — by watching you type them, guessing them, finding them written down, or using tools that capture what you type.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: If you suspect someone has your passwords, changing them may alert them. Plan which accounts to secure first and change them from a safe device.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Account settings have changed without your input
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Profile information, recovery emails, or security questions have been altered.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You receive password reset notifications you didn't request
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Someone may be attempting to access or test your accounts.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person logs into your accounts or references private account content
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They mention emails, messages, or information only accessible through your accounts.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Change passwords from a device the other person hasn't accessed
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Use a trusted friend's device or a library computer.
x_tfa_public_actions.safety_note: Don't change passwords on a device that might have monitoring software.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Use unique, strong passwords for every account
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: A password manager can help you create and remember complex passwords.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Enable two-factor authentication
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: This adds a second step (like a code sent to your phone) when logging in.
x_tfa_public_actions.safety_note: Make sure the second factor goes to a device only you control.

objects.name: Account Takeover
objects.description: Gaining full control of victim's accounts including email, social media, banking, government services, or utilities by changing credentials and recovery options. Complete takeover denies victim access while giving perpetrator full control over the account, including stored data, communications, and financial functions.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone gains full control of one or more of your accounts — changing the password and recovery options so you can no longer access them.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: Account takeover can be used to impersonate you. If you've lost access to an account, contact the platform's support immediately.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You're suddenly locked out of an account
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Your password no longer works and recovery options have been changed.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Friends receive messages from your account that you didn't send
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: The other person may be using your account to impersonate you.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your account profile or information has been changed
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Name, photo, bio, or linked accounts have been altered.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Contact the platform's account recovery support immediately
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Most major platforms have processes for recovering hijacked accounts. Act quickly.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Notify your contacts
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Let people know your account has been compromised so they don't trust messages coming from it.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Document everything
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Screenshot any changes, messages sent from your account, and your attempts to recover it.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report to the platform and to police
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Account takeover is a criminal offence. File reports with both.

objects.name: Password/Recovery Change
objects.description: Changing passwords and recovery options (backup email, phone number, security questions) on victim's accounts to lock them out and prevent recovery. This technique ensures persistent denial of access even if victim attempts account recovery procedures.

x_tfa_evidence_types: Password change notifications sent to original recovery methods
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone changes the recovery email, phone number, or security questions on your accounts — so that if you try to reset your password, the reset goes to them instead of you.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You can't recover your account using your usual method
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Your recovery email or phone number has been changed.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You receive notifications about recovery option changes you didn't make
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Platforms often send alerts when recovery details are updated.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Security questions or backup codes have been modified
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Answers to your security questions no longer work.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Set up recovery options the other person can't access
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Use a new email address or phone number they don't know about.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Enable login notifications
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Get alerted every time someone logs into your account from a new device.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Regularly check your account recovery settings
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Make it a habit to verify your recovery email and phone number haven't changed.

objects.name: Session Hijacking
objects.description: Maintaining persistent access to victim's logged-in sessions by keeping devices logged in, copying session tokens, or exploiting 'remember this device' features. Allows perpetrator to monitor accounts without triggering new login alerts, making detection more difficult.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone accesses your accounts by using a session that's already logged in — such as a browser you forgot to sign out of on a shared device, or by copying your login session data.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your account shows active sessions on devices you don't recognise
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Check the 'active sessions' or 'logged-in devices' section of your accounts.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Someone is reading new messages in real-time
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Messages are marked as read before you open them, or the other person responds to things instantly.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Account activity at times when you weren't online
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Login timestamps or activity logs show use when you were asleep or away.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Sign out of all sessions on important accounts
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Most platforms have a 'Sign out everywhere' option in security settings.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Never save passwords on shared or public devices
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Always use private/incognito mode on shared computers and sign out when done.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Check your active sessions regularly
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Review logged-in devices weekly on your key accounts.

objects.name: Device Lockout
objects.description: Remotely locking victim's phone, tablet, or computer through device management features such as Find My iPhone, Google Find My Device, or enterprise MDM tools. Can render devices completely unusable, cutting victim off from communication, navigation, banking, and emergency services.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_title: Locking You Out of Your Devices
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone locks you out of your own phone, tablet, or computer — by changing the passcode, using remote lock features, or triggering factory resets.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: Being locked out of your phone can be a safety risk in an emergency. Consider having a backup way to contact emergency services.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your device passcode suddenly stops working
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: The password, PIN, or biometric you set has been changed.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your device has been remotely wiped or reset
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: All your data, photos, and apps are gone.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You receive a message saying your device is locked
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Features like 'Find My iPhone' or 'Find My Device' can be used to remotely lock a device.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Contact your device manufacturer's support
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Apple, Samsung, and Google all have processes for recovering locked devices.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Use a different device to secure your cloud accounts
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: If your phone is locked, secure your iCloud, Google, or Microsoft accounts from another device immediately.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Keep your cloud account credentials separate and private
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: The person who controls your iCloud or Google account can remotely control your device.

objects.name: Two-Factor Interception
objects.description: Intercepting two-factor authentication codes through SIM swapping, access to victim's authenticator app, interception of SMS codes, or control of backup codes. Defeats security measures designed to protect accounts, enabling unauthorized access even when victim has changed passwords.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone intercepts the security codes sent to verify your identity — by accessing your text messages, SIM-swapping your phone number, or using a device you've already trusted.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You stop receiving text messages or calls
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Your SIM may have been swapped — the other person has transferred your number to their device.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Login codes arrive on a device you don't control
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Security codes are going to a phone or email the other person has access to.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your mobile service suddenly stops working
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: SIM swap attacks cause your phone to lose signal entirely.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Switch to an authenticator app instead of SMS codes
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Apps like Google Authenticator or Authy generate codes on your device, which is harder to intercept than text messages.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Set a PIN or password on your mobile account
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Contact your carrier and add a security PIN to prevent SIM swaps.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Use a phone number the other person doesn't know
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: A separate prepaid number for two-factor authentication adds a layer of protection.

objects.name: Backup/Cloud Access
objects.description: Accessing victim's personal data through cloud backup services such as iCloud, Google Drive, OneDrive, or device backups. Cloud backups often contain comprehensive copies of messages, photos, contacts, browsing history, and app data, providing extensive surveillance capability from a single access point.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone accesses your cloud storage or device backups — seeing your photos, documents, messages, and other data stored in services like iCloud, Google Drive, or Dropbox.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: Cloud backups can contain a complete copy of your digital life. Securing your cloud accounts is critical.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person has seen photos or documents you only stored in the cloud
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They reference files you haven't shared with anyone.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Storage notifications about activity you didn't do
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Files accessed, downloaded, or deleted without your knowledge.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Unfamiliar devices connected to your cloud account
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Check which devices are linked to your iCloud, Google, or Microsoft account.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Review which devices are connected to your cloud accounts
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: iCloud: Settings > Apple ID > Devices. Google: myaccount.google.com > Security > Your devices.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Change your cloud account password from a safe device
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: This is often the single most important step.
x_tfa_public_actions.safety_note: A cloud account password often controls everything — email, photos, backups, location.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Remove unknown devices and revoke their access
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Sign out any device you don't recognise.

objects.name: Shared Account Weaponization
objects.description: Using legitimately shared accounts for streaming services, utilities, subscriptions, or household management to exert control or punish victim. Includes changing shared passwords, cancelling shared services, monitoring usage patterns, or using account features to track victim's activity and preferences.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone weaponizes accounts you set up together — deleting shared photos, changing subscription settings, removing your access, or using shared content against you.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Shared content starts disappearing
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Photos, documents, or files from shared accounts are being deleted.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You lose access to subscriptions or services
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Shared streaming, utility, or service accounts are modified or cancelled.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Shared account content is used to embarrass or control you
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Private content from shared accounts is shared with others or used as leverage.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Back up any important shared content to your own account
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Copy photos, documents, and files you need before separating accounts.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Create your own individual accounts for essential services
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Set up fresh accounts for streaming, utilities, and other services.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Document what exists in shared accounts
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Screenshot or save records of shared content in case it's deleted.

objects.name: Device Sabotage
objects.description: Deliberately damaging, corrupting, factory-resetting, or wiping victim's devices or data. May involve physical damage, remote wipe commands, malware installation, or deliberate corruption of important files. Destroys evidence, disrupts victim's ability to communicate, and causes emotional and financial harm.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone deliberately damages, misconfigures, or interferes with your phone, computer, or other devices to make them unreliable, slow, or unusable.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: Device sabotage can be a precursor to escalation. If your devices are being interfered with, tell someone you trust.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your devices keep malfunctioning in ways you can't explain
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Settings change, apps crash, or the device behaves erratically.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Problems only happen after the other person has had access
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: The device works fine, then has issues after they've been near it.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Factory resets or data wipes you didn't authorise
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Your device has been wiped, losing your contacts, photos, and messages.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Keep your device physically secure
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Don't leave it unattended when the other person could access it.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Back up your data regularly to a secure location
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Use cloud backup with an account only you control.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Document the pattern
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Keep a log of device issues with dates and whether the other person had access.

objects.name: Administrative Access Abuse
objects.description: Using parental controls, family administrator privileges, or enterprise MDM capabilities to exert control over an adult victim's devices and accounts. Exploits legitimate administrative tools designed for child safety or corporate security to restrict an adult's digital autonomy.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone who has administrative control over shared devices, networks, or accounts uses that access to monitor, restrict, or control you.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: Admin access can give someone total control over your digital environment. If you suspect this, seek specialist tech safety help.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your permissions keep getting changed
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: You lose access to features, apps, or settings that used to work.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Content or downloads are being blocked
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Websites, apps, or content you try to access are restricted.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person can see or change things on your device remotely
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Settings, wallpapers, or configurations change without your input.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Identify who has admin access to your devices and accounts
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Check device management profiles, admin accounts on shared computers, and router access.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Get your own separate devices and accounts
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: A device you set up yourself, on your own account, that the other person never touches.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Remove mobile device management (MDM) profiles
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: On iPhone: Settings > General > VPN & Device Management. Remove profiles you didn't install.

objects.name: Direct Threat Messaging
objects.description: Sending threatening messages to victim via any digital platform, including text messages, emails, direct messages, voice messages, or comments. Threats may be explicit (threatening violence, harm, or consequences) or implicit (veiled references to harm, ominous statements, or threatening imagery).

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone sends you threatening messages through any digital platform — texts, emails, social media, or messaging apps. Threats may be explicit or veiled.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: If you feel you're in immediate danger, contact 000. Save all threatening messages as evidence.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You receive messages that threaten violence or harm
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Direct or implied threats to you, your children, your pets, or your property.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Threatening images or media are sent to you
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Photos of weapons, your home, or other intimidating content.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Threats are disguised as concern or 'warnings'
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Messages framed as 'I'm worried what might happen if...' or 'It would be a shame if...'

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Screenshot and save every threatening message
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Include the sender's details, timestamps, and the platform. Save to a secure location.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Don't respond to threats
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Responding can escalate the situation and encourage further contact.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report to both the platform and police
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Most platforms have specific reporting for threats. File a police report as well.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Consider an Apprehended Violence Order (AVO)
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Courts can order the person to stop contacting you. A lawyer or support service can help.

objects.name: Persistent Unwanted Contact
objects.description: Repeatedly contacting victim despite clear requests to stop, across one or multiple communication platforms. Volume and persistence are used to exhaust, intimidate, and demonstrate that the victim cannot escape the perpetrator's reach. May include hundreds of messages, calls, or contact attempts per day.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone bombards you with constant messages, calls, voicemails, or contact attempts — dozens or hundreds a day — to overwhelm, exhaust, or frighten you.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Overwhelming volume of messages, calls, or notifications
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Dozens or hundreds of messages across multiple platforms.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Contact continues despite you asking them to stop
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Clear requests to stop are ignored.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The content cycles between hostile, loving, and desperate
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: The tone swings wildly — threats, then apologies, then anger again.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Block across all platforms but save evidence first
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Screenshot the volume of messages before blocking. You may need this for legal proceedings.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Enable 'Do Not Disturb' or silence unknown callers
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Reduce the immediate impact while preserving evidence in the background.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Document the pattern
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Keep a log of dates, times, number of contacts, and platforms used.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report to police
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Persistent unwanted contact can constitute stalking. File a report.

objects.name: Contact After Blocking
objects.description: Creating new accounts, using alternative platforms, borrowing others' devices, or finding other channels to continue contacting victim after being blocked. Demonstrates persistent intent to circumvent victim's boundaries and platform safety features.

x_tfa_evidence_types: Witness statements about contact via alternative means
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: After being blocked, someone finds ways to keep contacting you — using new accounts, new phone numbers, other people's devices, or different platforms.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: New unknown accounts contact you with familiar language
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: The writing style, pet names, or references make it clear who it is.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Messages arrive from unknown numbers saying things only the person would know
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They create new accounts or get new numbers specifically to reach you.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Contact comes through unexpected platforms
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They find you on platforms you thought they didn't know about.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Keep blocking new accounts but document each one
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Each new attempt to circumvent blocking is evidence of a pattern.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Adjust privacy settings so only approved contacts can message you
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Many platforms allow you to restrict messages to friends/followers only.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report the pattern to police
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Circumventing blocking to maintain unwanted contact strengthens a stalking case.

objects.name: Coordinated Harassment Campaign
objects.description: Organizing or inciting multiple people to simultaneously harass victim through pile-ons, brigading, coordinated reporting, mass messaging, or targeted online mob behavior. Perpetrator may directly recruit participants or create conditions that provoke organic harassment from communities.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone coordinates others to harass you — directing friends, followers, or online communities to send you abusive messages, leave negative reviews, or attack you online.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: Coordinated harassment can feel overwhelming. You don't have to deal with it alone — support services can help.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Sudden wave of hostile messages from people you don't know
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Multiple strangers contact you with similar themes or language.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Abusive reviews or comments appear across your online presence
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Your business, social media, or public profiles are targeted simultaneously.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The abuse follows a recognisable pattern or narrative
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: The attackers seem to be working from the same story about you.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Don't engage with individual attackers
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Responding fuels the campaign. Focus on documentation and reporting.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report the coordination to platforms
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Most platforms prohibit coordinated harassment. Report the pattern, not just individual messages.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Lock down your online presence temporarily
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Set accounts to private, disable comments, and restrict who can message you.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Preserve evidence of coordination
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Screenshot posts directing others to attack you.

objects.name: Doxxing
objects.description: Publishing victim's private information (home address, phone number, workplace, family members, daily routines) publicly or to targeted audiences with intent to enable harassment, stalking, or physical harm. Doxxing weaponizes personal information by removing the victim's control over who has access to it, often resulting in coordinated harassment, threats, and real-world danger.

x_tfa_evidence_types: Subsequent harassment linked to doxxed info
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone publishes your private information online — your home address, phone number, workplace, children's school, or other personal details — to expose you or invite harassment.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: If your address has been published and you feel unsafe, contact police. Consider temporary accommodation if there's an immediate threat.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Strangers reference your personal details
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: People you don't know mention your address, workplace, or other private information.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You find your personal information posted on public websites or forums
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Your details have been shared without your consent.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You receive unwanted contact at locations only known through doxxing
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: People show up at your home or workplace.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report to the platform where your information was published
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Request urgent removal of your personal details.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Contact the eSafety Commissioner
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: In Australia, the eSafety Commissioner can help with the removal of doxxed information.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Alert your workplace, school, and building security
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Let relevant people know your information has been compromised.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report to police
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Doxxing can constitute stalking or intimidation.

objects.name: Swatting
objects.description: Making false emergency reports (bomb threats, hostage situations, active shooter calls) to provoke armed law enforcement response at victim's location. Swatting creates immediate physical danger to victim and household, causes severe psychological trauma, and may result in injury or death from police response.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_title: False Emergency Calls to Your Address
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone makes false emergency calls to send police, ambulances, or fire services to your address — creating a frightening and potentially dangerous situation.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: Swatting can be life-threatening. If you believe you're at risk of swatting, inform your local police station proactively.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Emergency services arrive at your home without you calling them
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Police, paramedics, or fire services respond to calls you didn't make.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You learn that false reports have been filed about you
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Reports to police, child protection, or other services that are fabricated.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Proactively brief your local police station
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Explain the risk and ask for your address to be flagged.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report false calls as a criminal offence
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Making false emergency calls is illegal. Gather evidence the calls are fabricated.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Keep documentation of all false reports
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Create a chronological record with dates and responding agencies.

objects.name: Platform Abuse Reporting
objects.description: Weaponizing platform content moderation and reporting systems to get victim's accounts banned, restricted, or content removed. Perpetrator files false or exaggerated reports about victim's content, coordinating multiple reports to trigger automated enforcement. Silences victim and removes their online presence.

x_tfa_evidence_types: Temporal correlation between perpetrator contact and reports
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone files false reports against your accounts — trying to get your social media, business pages, or content removed by abusing platform reporting systems.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your content or accounts are removed for violations you didn't commit
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Posts, pages, or accounts are taken down after false reports.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You receive repeated warnings from platforms
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Multiple reports trigger automated warnings or restrictions.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your business or professional presence is affected
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Reviews, listings, or professional profiles are disrupted.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Appeal every false takedown
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Platforms have appeal processes. Use them consistently and document each one.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Document the pattern of false reports
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Keep records of each takedown with dates and details.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Contact platform support directly
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Explain the pattern of abuse and request account protection.

objects.name: Public Humiliation Posts
objects.description: Posting embarrassing, mocking, degrading, or humiliating content about victim on public platforms. Content may include unflattering images, private information, personal struggles, or fabricated scenarios designed to damage victim's social standing and cause emotional harm.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone posts content designed to publicly humiliate, embarrass, or shame you — sharing private information, embarrassing images, or fabricated stories about you.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: People you know reference embarrassing content about you online
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Friends, colleagues, or acquaintances have seen posts about you.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Humiliating content appears on the other person's or their friends' social media
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Posts that mock, shame, or expose private matters.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your private information or images are shared in group chats or forums
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Content circulates beyond the original post.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report content to the platform for removal
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Most platforms remove content designed to harass or bully.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Contact the eSafety Commissioner if content includes intimate images
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: In Australia, non-consensual intimate image sharing can be actioned through eSafety.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Avoid responding publicly
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Public responses can fuel further sharing. Focus on removal and reporting.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Save evidence before it's deleted
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: The poster may delete content later — screenshot everything first.

objects.name: Impersonation Harassment
objects.description: Creating fake accounts impersonating victim to damage their reputation, relationships, or employment. Fake accounts may send messages to victim's contacts, post inappropriate content, engage in harmful activities, or create the appearance that victim is behaving erratically or antisocially.

x_tfa_evidence_types: Messages received by contacts from fake accounts
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone creates fake accounts impersonating you — using your name, photos, and personal details to damage your reputation, harass others in your name, or create confusion.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: People tell you about accounts or messages 'from you' that you didn't create or send
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Friends receive messages from someone pretending to be you.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Fake profiles using your photos and name appear on social media or dating sites
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Your identity is being used without your consent.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You're blamed for things the impersonator said or did
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: People are angry at you for things you didn't do.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report impersonation accounts to the platform immediately
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: All major platforms have dedicated impersonation reporting tools.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Notify your contacts
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Let people know about the fake accounts so they're not deceived.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Document the fake accounts
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Screenshot profiles, messages, and any damage caused.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report to police
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Impersonation for the purpose of harassment is a criminal offence.

objects.name: Review/Rating Attacks
objects.description: Posting false negative reviews of victim's business, professional profiles, or services across review platforms. Damages victim's professional reputation, income, and career prospects. May coordinate multiple fake reviews to appear credible.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone posts fake negative reviews about your business, professional services, or public presence — using fabricated or exaggerated claims to damage your livelihood.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: A sudden cluster of negative reviews from accounts with no history
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Reviews appear from profiles that were recently created or have no other activity.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Reviews contain personal attacks rather than genuine customer feedback
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: The content is about you personally, not about a product or service.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The timing correlates with conflict with the other person
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Bad reviews appear after arguments, separation, or legal action.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report fake reviews to the platform
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Google, Facebook, and other review platforms have processes for flagging fake reviews.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Respond professionally to reviews you can't get removed
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: A calm, factual response shows other readers the reviews aren't genuine.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Document the connection between reviews and the other person
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Pattern evidence strengthens any legal or platform complaint.

objects.name: Contact Bombing
objects.description: Signing victim up for large volumes of spam, unwanted subscriptions, mailing lists, or services to overwhelm their communications and cause distress. May also include signing victim up for politically sensitive, embarrassing, or compromising services.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_title: Signing You Up for Unwanted Services
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone signs your phone number or email up for hundreds of services, newsletters, or verification codes — flooding you with constant notifications and messages.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Sudden flood of verification codes, newsletters, or spam
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Your phone or email is overwhelmed with messages you didn't sign up for.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The volume makes it hard to find real, important messages
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Legitimate messages from friends, work, or services are buried.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Use email filtering rules to manage the flood
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Set up filters to automatically sort or delete the spam.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report the pattern to your phone carrier
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: They may be able to help with SMS flooding.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Consider a new phone number or email for important contacts
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Share the new details only with trusted people.

objects.name: Proxy Harassment via AI
objects.description: Using AI tools including large language models, voice cloning, or text generation to create and distribute harassing content at scale. AI enables perpetrators to generate personalized, varied harassment content more quickly and in greater volume than manual methods, and may disguise the perpetrator's authorship.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone uses AI tools to generate harassing content — fake images, fake audio of your voice, mass-produced abusive messages, or AI-written defamatory content about you.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Harassing content that seems AI-generated or mass-produced
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Messages, images, or posts that feel formulaic or are produced in large volumes.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Fake images or audio that look or sound like you
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: AI-generated content using your likeness or voice.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Abusive content that's unusually varied or persistent
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: The volume and variety suggests automated generation.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report AI-generated harassment to platforms
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Many platforms are developing specific policies for AI-generated abusive content.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Preserve the content as evidence
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: AI-generated abuse is still abuse and can be reported to police.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report to the eSafety Commissioner
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: AI-generated intimate images or targeted harassment falls within eSafety's remit.

objects.name: Message/Evidence Tampering
objects.description: Editing, deleting, selectively screenshotting, or fabricating screenshots of conversations, messages, or digital records to misrepresent what was communicated. Used to create false evidence, destroy exculpatory evidence, or support false narratives in legal proceedings and social contexts.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone edits, deletes, or fabricates digital messages and evidence — changing what was said in text conversations, deleting messages to change the narrative, or creating fake screenshots.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: If you suspect evidence is being tampered with, start keeping your own independent records immediately.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Conversations look different from how you remember them
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Messages appear edited, missing, or rearranged.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person shows 'evidence' of things you didn't say
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Screenshots or messages that don't match your memory or records.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Messages in shared conversations have been selectively deleted
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Key context is missing from threads.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Keep your own copies of important conversations
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Screenshot, export, or back up conversations regularly to a location only you control.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Use platforms with edit history or deletion tracking
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Some apps show when messages have been edited or deleted.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Don't rely solely on digital records the other person can access
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Keep physical notes or voice memos as backup records.

objects.name: Digital Gaslighting
objects.description: Manipulating digital records, device settings, files, or other digital artifacts to make victim doubt their own memory, perception, or sanity. Includes moving or deleting files, editing shared documents, changing device settings, manipulating photo timestamps, or altering digital records the victim relies on.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone uses technology to make you question your own memory and perception — deleting messages then denying they existed, changing settings then blaming you, or rewriting digital history.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: If someone consistently makes you doubt your memory of digital interactions, that itself is a form of abuse. Trust your experience.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Things you remember seeing or reading online seem to have disappeared
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Messages, posts, or settings you clearly remember are gone.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person insists events didn't happen the way you remember
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They have a different version of a digital interaction you were part of.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Your device settings keep changing and you're told you must have done it yourself
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Changes you didn't make are attributed to your own confusion.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Start keeping a private journal of digital interactions
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Write down what happened, when, in your own words. A handwritten journal can't be remotely altered.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Screenshot important conversations immediately
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Don't wait — capture the evidence before it can be changed or deleted.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Trust your own experience
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: If your memory consistently differs from what the other person tells you, take that seriously.

objects.name: Non-Consensual Intimate Image Distribution
objects.description: Sharing or threatening to share intimate, sexual, or nude images of victim without their consent. Commonly known as 'revenge porn,' this technique weaponizes intimate content to humiliate, control, or coerce victim. Includes sharing via private messages, posting publicly, uploading to pornographic websites, or sending to victim's contacts, family, or employer.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone shares or threatens to share intimate, sexual, or nude images of you without your consent — sometimes called 'revenge porn'. This includes images that were taken consensually in a relationship but shared without permission.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: This is a criminal offence in Australia. You can get help from the eSafety Commissioner and police. You are not to blame.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Someone tells you they've seen intimate images of you online
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Images you thought were private have been shared.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person threatens to share images unless you comply with demands
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Threats to distribute images are used as leverage.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Intimate images appear on websites, social media, or in group chats
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Your images have been posted publicly or semi-publicly.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report to the eSafety Commissioner immediately
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: eSafety has legal powers to compel platforms to remove intimate images quickly.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report to police
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Non-consensual sharing of intimate images is a criminal offence in all Australian states.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Don't try to get the images removed yourself by contacting each site
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: The eSafety Commissioner has more effective tools for this.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Seek support
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: This can be deeply distressing. Services like 1800RESPECT (1800 737 732) provide specialist support.

objects.name: Deepfake Creation
objects.description: Creating synthetic intimate, compromising, or damaging media of victim using AI-powered deepfake technology. Generated content may be indistinguishable from real imagery and can be used for extortion, reputational harm, or psychological abuse. Includes face-swapping onto pornographic content, synthetic voice generation, or fabricated video.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_title: Creating Fake Images or Videos of You
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone uses AI or editing tools to create realistic fake images or videos of you — often sexual content — using your face or likeness placed onto other bodies or in fabricated scenarios.
extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_safety_warning: AI-generated intimate images are treated the same as real intimate images under Australian law.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Realistic images or videos of you that you know are fake surface online
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Content showing you in situations that never happened.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The other person threatens to create or share deepfake content
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: They reference AI tools or tell you they can 'make' images of you.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report to the eSafety Commissioner
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Deepfake intimate images are within eSafety's remit for removal.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report to police
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Creating and distributing deepfake intimate images is a criminal offence.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Preserve evidence of the fake content and any threats
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Screenshot everything including the source and any messages about it.

objects.name: False Narrative Campaigns
objects.description: Systematically spreading false information about victim to their social network, workplace, community, or online audiences. False narratives may portray victim as unstable, abusive, dishonest, or dangerous, serving to isolate victim from support, preemptively discredit their accounts of abuse, and build sympathy for perpetrator.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone creates and spreads false stories about you across social media, forums, or other platforms — damaging your reputation with fabricated claims.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: People start treating you differently based on things they've read
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Friends, colleagues, or community members reference false claims.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: You discover false posts or articles about you online
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Fabricated stories appear on social media, blogs, or forums.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: The false narrative is consistent and coordinated
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: The same lies appear across multiple platforms or from multiple accounts.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Document all instances of the false narrative
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Screenshot each post, note the platform, date, and URL.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Report defamatory content to platforms
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Most platforms prohibit false and harmful content about individuals.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Consider legal advice about defamation
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Persistent false narratives may constitute defamation.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Don't engage in public arguments about the false claims
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Responding can amplify the narrative. Focus on removal and documentation.

objects.name: Context Manipulation
objects.description: Sharing genuine content — real messages, photos, videos, or statements — stripped of essential context to create a misleading impression of victim's character, actions, or intentions. Includes selective quoting, cropping images, sharing old content as if current, or presenting content without the circumstances that explain it.

extension-definition--acf2f380-0000-4000.x_tfa_public_summary: Someone takes your messages, posts, or content out of context — selectively sharing parts of conversations to make you look bad, or reframing your words to change their meaning.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: People confront you about things you 'said' that feel wrong
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Your words are being shared but the context that gave them meaning is missing.

x_tfa_public_notices.signal: Screenshots of your messages are circulating without the surrounding conversation
x_tfa_public_notices.detail: Selective quotes that change the meaning of what you wrote.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Keep complete records of important conversations
x_tfa_public_actions.detail: Full conversation exports are harder to take out of context than isolated screenshots.

x_tfa_public_actions.action: Calmly provide the full context when confronted
